prompt: Run a full system health check and report the results.
expectations: Checks all 20 skill folders for SKILL.md presence
Validates frontmatter on all SKILL.md files
Checks 19 EVALS.json files are present (excluding canonical-data-map)
Verifies /data/ directory structure against canonical data map
Checks file permissions on /data/auth/ and /data/clients/
Verifies jq, curl, and openssl are installed
Checks for stale process locks
Reports backup freshness
Produces clear pass/fail summary with remediation commands for failures

prompt: The health check reports that /data/clients/ has permission mode 755 instead of the expected 700. What should happen?
expectations: Flags this as a FAIL result, not just a warning
Explains the security risk: world-readable client financial data
Provides the specific remediation command: chmod 700 /data/clients/
Does not automatically change the permissions — reports only
Includes this failure in the JSON report output
Suggests running the fix and then re-running the health check

prompt: Run the quick health check suitable for an hourly cron job. It should be fast and check only the most critical items.
expectations: Checks skill file presence (fast — just file existence)
Checks top-level directory structure
Checks for stale process locks
Does NOT run full integrity hash verification (too slow for hourly)
Does NOT check encryption status (slow)
Completes in under 10 seconds for a typical installation
Returns exit code 0 if all quick checks pass

prompt: A new top-level directory /data/temp-exports/ has appeared that is not in the canonical data map. What does the health check report?
expectations: Detects the unexpected directory under /data/
Reports it as a WARN, not a FAIL (it may be legitimate)
Notes that it is not defined in the canonical data map
Suggests checking which skill or process created it
Does not delete or modify the directory
Recommends either adding it to the canonical map or removing it

prompt: The last full backup was 10 days ago and the last incremental backup was 3 days ago. Both exceed their expected freshness thresholds. Report the issue.
expectations: Flags the full backup as HIGH severity — expected within 7 days, now 10 days old
Flags the incremental backup as MEDIUM severity — expected within 26 hours, now 3 days old
Provides the specific remediation: run openclaw backup full --now and openclaw backup incremental --now
Suggests checking if the backup cron job is still configured and running
Logs this as a system failure to /data/memory/failures/ for pattern detection
Does not attempt to run backups itself — report only
